course.subject: IEDA
course.name: Probability for Engineers
course.description: This is a systematic introduction to basic probability theory for engineering, including sample space and sampling methods, calculus of probability, conditional probability, joint distribution, moment generating functions, the law of large numbers and central limit theorem. Along the course, students will learn a wide range of discrete and continuous probability distributions, which are important and useful in various applications.
course.prerequisites: MATH 1014 OR MATH 1020 OR MATH 1024
course.exclusions: IEDA 2510 (prior to 2018-19), ELEC 2600, ELEC 2600H, MATH 2421, MATH 2431

reviews.author: Tommy Li
reviews.title: MATH 2520 Introduction to Probabilty
reviews.comment_content:
For most 2000 level MATH course, there are two (or more) version of the same course. For example, MATH 2011/2023, MATH 2111/2121 and MATH 2351/2352. One of the two is introduced more rigorous than the other. However, the probability introduction course seems to be missing.... No! It went to the IEDA department. :D

This course is a non-rigorous introduction to probability. This course focuses on the computation and coding, and almost no proofs are covered in the course. The concepts are mostly introduced informally, even basic set theory knowledge is not required.

Topics included:
I. Descriptive Statistics
II. Elements of Probability (basic definitions)
III. Random Variables (discrete, continuous, joint distributions)
IV. Limiting Theorems (law of large numbers, CLT)

Also, there are about three python tutorials for basic scipy packages and graph plotting.
reviews.comment_teaching: The prof. introduces the concepts clearly with explanations. You can see markings flying around his slides. He teaches pretty slow that most students can catch up easily. There is even no prerequisites needed like high school probability. In my perspective, it is sometimes quite boring as he spent too much time on trivial concepts (although it is good he does that).
reviews.comment_grading:
You won't get such a good grade if you perform equally well in a MATH course. The top students from MATH courses are missing so the curve is pulled up nicely. Most of the problems in exams are easy (but a few of them is annoying) so being careful is quite important.

Score statistics (and my score):
Midterm 1 (15%): 98/100 (Mean: 69, SD: 15.9, Max: 98)
Midterm 2 (25%): 98/100 (Mean: 68.82, SD: 18.97, Max: 98)
Final exam (45%): 87/100 (Mean: 63.6, SD: not released, Max: 95)
Homework (15%): 39.5/40
Overall: 93.1625% -> A+

Attached are score distributions of both midterms.
reviews.comment_workload:
The overall workload of the course is quite light considering the amount of homework and the preparation work for the exams.

Exams:
To be honest, I did not revise much for the two midterms. Most of the materials are DSE level and you do not need to pay too much effort. So, there is very little workload in the middle of the term. On the other hand, you should spend some time preparing for the exam. Writing a good cheatsheet would help you apply the formula faster, and clearing up your concepts meanwhile. You have to be crystal clear about the concepts of correlation and independence, or else you might get them wrong easily.

Homework:
Although there are 8 assignments, we only have to submit 4 of them. They would not take you a lot of time.

Lecture/tutorial:
Attendance is not mandatory for both lectures and tutorial. My suggestion is to skip the tutorials and find extra materials online/ from a textbook.

reviews.author: 16y39y
reviews.title: first half is very easy but later it gets really hard
reviews.comment_content:
The exact contents are the same as the reviews below, so I won't list the subtopics and talk about my thoughts instead.

Python Basics
Quite useful python coding (basic operations, importing packets like matplotlib, pandas etc.) Good starting point for learning data analysis.

Module 1 - Descriptive Statistics
Mostly high school stuff, talks about how to describe data with various charts (which to use in each case). Most of this content doesn't get tested in the end, the only new and useful thing I learned in this module is the Chebyshev's inequality.

Module 2 - Elements of Probability
I took M1 in high school so this was all easy M1 stuff (disclaimer: my M1 isn't that good either), but this module should be easy for those who have no background as well. Just basic multiplying and dividing most of the time, some annoying counting but nothing ridiculously hard.

Module 3a - Random Variables (Discrete)
Pmf, cdf of discrete random variables (basically Poisson, Bernoulli and Binomial), not too hard since it's just summation, no calculus.

Module 3b - Random Variables (Continuous)
Pdf, cdf of continuous distributions (exponential, standard normal etc.), this is where things start to get a bit hard and confusing since there is calculus involved. In my opinion, still manageable with reasonable effort.

Module 3c - Joint Distribution
Joint distribution and conditional distribution/expectation with multiple (mainly 2) variables. This module gets ridiculously difficult especially if you have no multivariable calculus background (which I believe is the case for most year 2 IEDA students in Fall sem). The basic examples covered in class are easy to understand and helpful, but the homework and exam questions are a whole different level.

Module 4 - Limiting Theorems
This part seems easy compared to 3c. Should be fine once you understand the applications of law of large numbers and central limit theorem.

I enjoyed the content, it was useful and quite challenging.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Zhang Jiheng is good at teaching. He has the exceptional talent of making complex concepts sound more friendly and understandable. I appreciate that he never over-complicated stuff and tailored the course to beginners with little to no background.

He prepares useful examples in class and really makes us understand the point of learning all this content (applications in different industries and later IEDA courses). He sounds like he genuinely believes in the stuff he teaches and backs it up with actual knowledge and examples. He teaches with heart and you can tell he really cares.

He is also very nice to the students (even to those who challenge him in class. Yes, it actually happened.) He replies to all emails as much as he can and sometimes gives hints for the homework.

Most importantly, it is evident that he pays attention to students' opinions and actually makes appropriate responses. For example, a student criticised him on Canvas for setting midterm questions that could be easily googled. In the final, he set very unique and difficult questions with niche notations and published the paper in .jpg format (don't know if this has to do with the incident, but undeniably it worked).

He teaches the simple examples of multivariable calculus very well - he helps us visualize by drawing graphs and using different colours. He explains them so well that you're tricked into thinking you can handle those problems - and then you look at the homework and exam questions then you realize you don't even know how to start. Sometimes I wished he could have gone over some more difficult examples in class as well.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grade statistics are rarely published (all we know are the min, max and mean from Canvas) but from my experience the grading was surprisingly good.

Homework (15%): 149/155 (above mean)
Midterm (30%): 88/100 (mean: 68.4)
Final (55%): 51/100 (the stats only appeared for 5 minutes, I believe the mean was 38 and the max was somewhere around 80?)

Finally got an A, which is really good especially considering my horrible final mark and mediocre midterm. I was quite surprised at the grade.
reviews.comment_workload: Weekly homework, most of which were fine. There were 8 in total, I personally found the first 5 very easy, 6th was a bit hard and 7th and 8th were very hard for me. The easy ones took me under an hour while the hard ones took me many hours, and I still got wrong lmao

reviews.author: Genisusl
reviews.title: å»£æ±è©±è©•æ¸¬
reviews.comment_content:
Ch1 Descriptive Statistics
(Describing Data Sets, Summarizing Data Sets, Chebyshev's Inequality for Data, Normal Data Sets, Paired Data Sets)

Ch2 Elements of Probability
(Sample Spaces & Events, Venn Diagrams, Axioms of Probability, Counting, Conditional Probability, Bayes's Formula, Independent Events)

Ch3A Random Variable (Discrete)
(PMF & CDF, Expectation, Variance, Bernouli Distribution, Binomial Distribution, Hypergometric Distribution, Geometric Distribution, Possion Distribution, MGF )

Ch3B Random Variable (Continuous)
(PDF & CDF, Expectation, Variance, MGF, Comparision between Discrete and Continuous, Uniform Distribution, Expotential Distribution, Normal Distribution, Chi-Square Distribution, t-Distribution)

Ch3C Joint Distribution and Covariance
(Joint Distribution, Independence, LOTUS-2D, Conditional Distributions, Variance & Covariance)

Ch4 Limiting Theorems
(Weak Law of Large Numbers, Markov's Inequality, Chebyshev's Inequality, Central Limit Theorem, Connection to Statistics)

reviews.author: PyothePro
reviews.title: Interesting concepts
reviews.comment_content:
Module 1: Descriptive Statistics - you probably already learned this before
Module 2: Elements of Probability - You probably already learned this before as well. There might be some new concepts like Bayes' theorem, but it's easy.
Module 3-a,b: Discrete and Continuous Random Variable - a bit more difficult than 1&2, but manageable.
Module 3-c: Joint Distribution & Covariance - This is where most students struggle. Multivariable Calculus and the following complicated cdf calculations will make you want to close your ear and scream.
Module 4: Limiting Theorems - Not so difficult.


I advise you to take a look at Multivariable Calculus before you take this course if you have the time.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Jiheng made sure nobody was left out. He explained every details carefully so that everyone can understand.
Unfortunately, because so many of his classes got cancelled due to typhoons, festivals, etc, he had to rush through the 3rd and 4th module, which are actually the most important and difficult part of this course :(
The TAs were willing to help whenever I needed help, which was nice.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm 1: (100/100) (Mean: 86.2)
Midterm 2: (66/100) (Mean: 57)
Final: Not released, but I remember it being extremely difficult. Out of the 7 big questions, I think I solved 4 of them correctly, and merely "attempted" to solve the rest. When I asked other classmates, it turns out I did pretty darn well.
Assignment: Close to full mark. most of them are 100 percent, with a couple being 9 or 9.5 out of 10.


...apparently I ended up getting an A+ (yay)
reviews.comment_workload: Although it sounds annoying to have 2 midterms, it isn't too bad. The midterm gives you an opportunity to actively review content, while each of them is only a small part of your grade. So don't be too stressed.

reviews.author: jacko
reviews.title: Good course overall imo
reviews.comment_content: The course is more like an intro to probability as the math involved is pretty simple and most of the proofs to concepts aren't very rigorous. A lot of important concepts in probability theory are omitted in this course for the sake of simplicity for the students which is understandable.
reviews.comment_teaching: Jiheng is a very passionate and charismatic prof; I look forward to taking another one of his courses.
reviews.comment_workload: Very light workload but if you want to gain a good understanding of the concepts, you'll have to put in more time and practice as it can be tricky to grasp for many people. The lectures only cover the concepts rather lightly and the homework is nearly nonexistent for this course so you'll have to do more practice problems on the side to really build an understanding. If you can consistently put in a couple hours of work each week into doing practice, you can probably attain a good grade. Watching youtube videos also helped me immensely for this course as it helped me tie all the concepts together.

reviews.author: Tsuki
reviews.title: Interesting Course and imo good grading
reviews.comment_content:
I don't usually write a review for courses but this was a decent course.

Tentative Course Outline:

1. Preliminaries
â€¢Counting, combinatorics, and classic probability
â€¢Basis calculus

2. Elements of Probability
â€¢Sample space and events
â€¢Axioms of probability
â€¢Conditional probability
â€¢Bayes rule
â€¢Independence

3. Random Variables
â€¢Discrete random variables
â€¢Continuous random variables
â€¢Joint distribution and covariance

4. Moment
â€¢Expectation
â€¢Variance and higher-order moments
â€¢Moment generating function
â€¢Conditional expectation

5. Limiting Theorems
â€¢Convergence
â€¢Law of large numbers
â€¢Central limit theorems

6. Applications
â€¢Introduction to stochastic simulation
â€¢Introduction to Stochastic process

This course only needs some knowledge of calculus
(Basic differentiating/integration)

The content was useful and may benefit in future job interviews.

* I think Chp 6 was not covered so it didn't come out in the exam.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof Chen is a reasonable prof, his slides are helpful and the questions in the exam are not too difficult.

He gave us some past papers and some additional exercises (optional) on Canvas. He also gave us a cheat sheet reference (to make our own) for finals.

Overall he wasn't the best at teaching after all this was his first year teaching at UST.

As for tutorials, I have not attended any so yea...no comment.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading: midterm (30%), final (50%), homework (20%).

Homework is best 4

Midterm
Mean: 77.82
Final
Mean: 55.57
(Cheat sheet allowed in both exams)

My grades: B+
I would say I could have gotten A- if I tried harder
Overall, I'm satisfied with the grading
reviews.comment_workload:
There was 5 homework
You can choose to skip one
Some of the homework can be a bit time-consuming so I recommend starting ASAP

Otherwise not much workload.

reviews.author: Wings
reviews.title: Second Half is challenging
reviews.comment_content:
The first half(Ch1-2) of the course is rather easy and straightforward but it is extremely difficult in the second half(after Ch3) which requires good calculus background. I suggest you guys start reading the sources from chapter 3 asap.

Due to extreme weather conditions, we lost 3 lessons which made our schedule extremely rushed in the last few lessons. It was quite hard for me to pick up plenty of new concepts in the study break before the final exam.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor spent a lot of time dealing with proofs and theory in the second half of the course. His instruction was clear. There are also a lot of new concepts and terms you have to be familiar with.

You can just skip all the tutorials since the TA was just reading the ppt. In case you have some questions to ask, you can stay.
reviews.comment_grading:
You have to be very careful and make sure you have read the sample quiz paper before the 2 midterms. I didn't revise the papers therefore I couldn't obtain a high grade in both of them.
I was below mean in two mid-terns but surprisingly got a B after final.
reviews.comment_workload:
less stress compared to math subjects
You can easily find sources from the internet

reviews.author: TwoSouls
reviews.comment_content:
1. Very brief introduction on Python
2. Descriptive Statistics (plots, mean, s.d. etc.)
3. Probability
4. Random Variable (discrete, continuous, joint distribution)
5. Limiting Theorems

Topic 1-3 are quite easy but 4-5 are the focus of the course which  you have to pay attention.
reviews.comment_teaching: The instructor and TAs are responsive. Since the content are well-explained and understandable, so the lectures are useful, especially for revision. I cannot comment on the tutorials because I skipped all of them.
reviews.comment_grading:
Assignments(15%):
1. 10/10
2. 19/20
3. 20/20
4. 19/20
5. 20/20
6. 20/20
7. 17/20
8. 24/25

Midterm(30%):
66/100
Mean: 68.4

Final(55%):
Around 35/100
(Instructor didn't release the result and related stat.)

Grade: B+
reviews.comment_workload: There are 8 assignments in this course. For each of them, we have around a week to complete it. The first half of them is easy but the second half required some calculus techniques.

reviews.author: Karin
reviews.comment_content: This course covers the general understanding of statistics, probabilities, and distributions.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Zhang provides the students with step by step explanation and comprehensive PowerPoint slides.
reviews.comment_grading: The overall grading was acceptable and reasonable.
reviews.comment_workload: The students were given an assignment every week which cover the latest materials learned in the class. Besides weekly assignments, there are both mid-term and final exams in this course. While the mid-term exam covers the first half of the course materials, the final exam covers all materials learned throughout the entire semester. There are no other workloads apart from the ones stated above.

reviews.author: procrastination
reviews.comment_content:
Module I:
Describing and Summarizing Data Sets
Chebyshevâ€™s Inequality for Data
Normal Data Sets
Paired Data Sets

Module II:
Sample Spaces & Events
Venn Diagrams
Axioms of Probability
Counting
Conditional Probability
Bayesâ€™ Formula
Independent Events

Module III(a):
PMF & CDF
Expectation
Variance
Bernoulli Variables
Binomial Variables
Hypergeometric
Geometric
MGF
Poisson

Module III(b):
PDF & CDF
Expectation
Variance
MGF
Uniform
Exponential
Normal
Normal Related

Module IV:
Law of Large Numbers
The Central Limit Theorem

There are some of the content which involve using multivariable calculus are not included in the examination as most of the students did not take MATH2011 before. And there are also some python included in the course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof Zhang is a good teacher that he delivers the content clearly and detailedly but he uses a lot of time in the introduction part which makes the lecture a bit boring.
There are several TAs in this course, some of them are not good at teaching but they are really helpful and they answer the questions really quick even after class. And there is one of the TA who always gives detailed explanation.
reviews.comment_grading:
i think the grading is fair.
I scored above mean in assignments and midterm and already got an A-
reviews.comment_workload: There are three assignments in total and two midterms in the course. The math part of the assignment is quite hard but it is quite similar to the midterms.

reviews.author: chingh
reviews.comment_content:
Basic probabilities.

Module I: (quite like introduction part)
Describing and Summarizing Data Sets
Chebyshevâ€™s Inequality for Data
Normal Data Sets
Paired Data Sets

Module II:
Sample Spaces & Events
Venn Diagrams
Axioms of Probability
Counting
Conditional Probability
Bayesâ€™ Formula
Independent Events

Module III(a): (discrete random variables)
PMF & CDF
Expectation
Variance
Bernoulli Variables
Binomial Variables
Hypergeometric
Geometric
MGF
Poisson

Module III(b): (continuous random variables)
PDF & CDF
Expectation
Variance
MGF
Uniform
Exponential
Normal
Normal Related (chi square, t distribution)

Module IV:
Law of Large Numbers
The Central Limit Theorem (not tested in final exam)


the first part (module I, II) is easy and it is like DSE level. then the content becomes harder but it is okay if you pay attention in class or ask TAs for help.

the content is a bit difficult to understand but when it comes to practice problems, you may find it super hard.......
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof Zhang spent lots of time in teaching module I, II , which are super easy.
Later for more difficult content, he used lots of example to explain the concept which made lecture interesting (but sometimes the teaching is so slow, so...... still a bit boring)
he explained the calculation and the formula in detail. it's not hard to follow and understand the math.

the first few tutorials teach python and after that tutorials are mostly revision of the concepts and content that is taught in lecture s with few practice problems. TAs are not good at teaching but they are willing to help. since only few students attend the tutorials , TAs  would try to make sure everyone in the tutorial understand the content and keep asking who cannot follow, etc.
beware only the question is posted on canvas, not the solutions.
reviews.comment_grading:
fairly good.
i got above mean in two midterm exams and a bit below mean in final, a bit above mean for the assignments. final grade: B+

mean of most of the assignments are 8-9 out of 10.

no attendence is taken in lectures and tutorials.
reviews.comment_workload:
only 3 assignments .
2 of them consists of math part + programming part (9+1 marks)
programming part is very easy. you just need to follow (copy?) the tutorial materials.
math part is sometimes challenging to me..

no projects no labs no quizes........

reviews.author: Terrancexxx
reviews.comment_content:
Basic concept about Probability
Focus mainly on practical problems in daily life
But not enough explanation about the Python, sometimes you have to learn it by yourself on the internet
reviews.comment_teaching:
Good, but sometimes wastes too much time on unnecessary calculation or concepts.
TAs are warmhearted, though sometimes make little mistakes.
In all, you can easily catch up with the pace of this course even if you skip 1 or 2 classes in this course, but better not too many of course.XD
reviews.comment_grading:
Good enough and also fair enough
2 midterms and 1 final
And sometimes you can argue about your grades
reviews.comment_workload:
workload is not heavy at all.
4 homework during the semester
had better divide more time for reading and learning the python codes provided by TAs.

reviews.author: Silvermoon213
reviews.title: A good course but lacked exercises
reviews.comment_content:
1. Descriptive Statistics:
- Axioms of probability
- Venn Diagrams
- Discrete random Variable
- Bernoulli Distribution (Binomial, Poisson, Hypergeometric, geometric)
- Continuous Random Variable
- Exponential, Normal, Uniform distribution
- Pre statistics course
reviews.comment_teaching: A lack of exercise and homework questions really burdened the students in especially understanding. All things considered, it was a good teaching and motivating as well.
reviews.comment_grading: It has been really nice grading, that the TA actually analyzes the answers and give you partial credits. In result the class average is not too low
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is pretty decent for a probability course. However, some of the homework questions are very difficult

reviews.author: Cccccjjj
reviews.title: IEDA 2520
reviews.comment_content:
1. Descriptive Statistics
â€¢ Frequency tables and graphs, histograms, leaf plots,
â€¢ Sample mean and variance, sample median, sample percentile
â€¢ Chebyshevâ€™s inequality for data

2. Elements of Probability
â€¢ Sample space and events
â€¢ Axioms of probability
â€¢ Conditional probability
â€¢ Bayes rule
â€¢ Independence

3. Random Variables
â€¢ Discrete random variables
â€¢ Continuous random variables
â€¢ Joint distribution and covariance

4. Limiting Theorems
â€¢ Law of large numbers
â€¢ Central limit theorems

Python is also taught in this course. But not very deep into this topic. Only a few MCs in the midterm tests and wasnâ€™t tested in the final exam.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Zhang is not bad but tends to spend too much time on trivial concepts. Also the TAs are not so into the course content, especially the python part.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grade is quite good.

midterm I (15%), midterm II (25%), final (45%), homework (15%).

Personally:
Assignment (in total): 27/30 (mean: 26.9)
Midterm 1: 84/100 (mean: 66.5 high: 98)
Midterm 2: 69/100 (mean: 52.9 high: 94)
Final: 76/100 (mean: 60.8 high: 85)

Final grade A
reviews.comment_workload:
3 graded maths assignments and 1 graded programming assignment.
2 midterm exams in lecture time in early October and early November.
1 final exam.
Single page A4 cheat sheet for midterm 1 and double page A4 for midterm 2 and final.
No project or presentation. No attendance is taken in both lecture and tutorial.

reviews.author: Potato2001
reviews.title: ieda2520
reviews.comment_content:
Module I:
(a) how to describe data using various tables, graphs, plot, charts
(b) what are the sample mean, median, variance
(c) what is the sample p percentile, quartile
(d) what is Chebyshevâ€™s inequality (for data), how to apply it
(e) what is sample correlation, how to use it to explain data

Module II:
(a) what are sample spaces and events
(b) what are the operation rules for events, how to apply them if you are given
examples of events in a sample space
(c) what are Axioms of probability and their implications
(d) how to apply the counting techniques (we learned in this course) and Axioms
of probability to calculate probability of an application problem
(e) what is conditional probability, how to calculate and apply it
(f) how to apply conditioning and Bayesâ€™s formula
(g) what is independence and how to apply it

Module IIIa:
(a) what is a discrete random variable
(b) what are CDF and pmf, their relationship; how to calculate probabilities using
them
(c) what is expectation and its properties, how to calculate
(d) what is variance and its properties, how to calculate
(e) how to apply properties of expectation and variance to simplify calculation
(f) what are moment generating functions and their properties, how to apply them
(g) Bernoulli
(h) Binomial
i. Binomial is independent sum of Bernoulli
ii. Binomial(n1,p) plus an independent Binomial(n2,p) will become Binomial(n1+
n2,p)
(i) Hypergeometric
(j) Geometric
k) Poisson
i. approximation of Poisson and Binomial
Module IIIb:
(a) what is a continuous random variable
(b) what are CDF and pdf, their relationship; how to calculate probabilities using
them
(c) what is expectation and its properties, how to calculate
(d) what is variance and its properties, how to calculate
(e) how to apply properties of expectation and variance to simplify calculation
(f) what are moment generating functions and their properties, how to apply them
(g) Uniform
(h) Exponential
i. memoryless property
ii. competition of two exponential r.v.â€™s
iii. the minimal of exponential r.v.â€™s
(i) Normal
i. how to calculate the probability of any normal r.v. using the standard
normal distribution
ii. what is symmetric property of normal
iii. what is independent sum of normal r.v.â€™s
iv. what is zÎ±
(j) t-distribution and tÎ±,n
(k) Chi square distribution and Ï‡2Î±,n
(l) Python commands
Module IIIc:
(a) what is joint distribution, how to do calculations (discrete, continuous)
(b) what is the relationship between joint distribution and independence
(c) 2D LOTUS and how to apply it
(d) what are conditional distributions
(e) how to calculate expectations using conditional distributions
(f) what is covariance
(g) how to apply properties of covariance for probability analysis
Module IV:
(a) what are Markov and Chebyshevâ€™s inequalities (for random variables), how to
apply
(b) what is Law of Large Numbers, how Chebyshevâ€™s inequality connects to it
(c) what is the Central Limit Theorem, how to use it.

reviews.author: Myyky00
reviews.comment_content:
The course is like an introduction to probability as the math involved is pretty simple and the proofs to some formula.  A lot of important concepts in probability theory are omitted in this course. Also learning how to use Python for plotting chart.

TEACHING

Jiheng is a very passionate and charismatic prof; I look forward to taking another one of his courses.

GRADING

Grading is quite good.

WORKLOAD

Very light workload but if you want to gain a good understanding of the concepts, you'll have to put in more time and practice as it can be tricky to grasp for many people. The lectures only cover the concepts rather lightly and the homework is nearly nonexistent for this course so you'll have to do more practice problems on the side to really build an understanding. If you can consistently put in a couple hours of work each week into doing practice, you can probably attain a good grade. Watching youtube videos also helped me immensely for this course as it helped me tie all the concepts together.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Jiheng is a very nice, and passionate a professor ; His teaching style is easily for us to understand the concepts.

.
reviews.comment_workload: Light workload with only one hw per module/ sub module. 2 midterm and 1 final exam only.
